Author: Muhammad Ali Jinnah

‚Ä¢ Drafted by Jinnah alone
‚Ä¢ Presented to Muslim League session (Delhi, March 1929)
‚Ä¢ Represented Muslim League's demands

rows.nehruReport:
Constitutional Structure:
‚Ä¢ Dominion Status (not independence)
‚Ä¢ Federal system with strong center
‚Ä¢ Responsible government
‚Ä¢ Bicameral legislature
‚Ä¢ Adult suffrage
‚Ä¢ Joint electorates (no separate electorates)
‚Ä¢ Linguistic provinces
‚Ä¢ Fundamental rights guaranteed

Rejected:
‚Ä¢ Separate electorates for Muslims
‚Ä¢ Reservation of seats beyond population proportion
rows.jinnah14Points:
Muslim Safeguards (14 Points):
1. Federal constitution with residuary powers to provinces
2. Provincial autonomy
3. All legislatures with adequate Muslim representation
4. 1/3 Muslim representation in Central Legislature
5. Separate electorates (till better relations)
6. No change in Muslim majority provinces without consent
7. Religious freedom
8. 1/3 Muslim ministers in Cabinet
9. No Bill affecting community if 3/4 oppose
10. Sindh separation from Bombay
11. Reforms in NWFP & Balochistan
12. Muslim representation in services
13. Constitutional safeguards for minorities
14. No constitutional change without states' consent

rows.nehruReport:
Congress: Accepted with reservations

Muslim League: Rejected
‚Ä¢ Jinnah opposed no separate electorates
‚Ä¢ Felt Muslim interests not protected
‚Ä¢ Demanded 1/3 representation at center

Youth: Dissatisfied
‚Ä¢ Jawaharlal Nehru, Subhash Bose wanted complete independence, not Dominion Status
rows.jinnah14Points:
Congress: Rejected
‚Ä¢ Felt excessive communal demands
‚Ä¢ Couldn't accept separate electorates
‚Ä¢ Federal structure would weaken center

Muslim League: Adopted
‚Ä¢ Became Muslim League's official position
‚Ä¢ Basis for future Pakistan demand

British: Ignored both

rows.nehruReport:
Positive:
‚Ä¢ Showed Indian capacity for constitutional thinking
‚Ä¢ Alternative to Simon Report
‚Ä¢ United effort initially

Negative:
‚Ä¢ Failed to satisfy Muslims
‚Ä¢ Exposed Hindu-Muslim differences
‚Ä¢ Dominion Status demand already outdated
‚Ä¢ Within year, Congress adopted Purna Swaraj
rows.jinnah14Points:
‚Ä¢ Last compromise attempt by Jinnah (before becoming communal)
‚Ä¢ Showed growing Muslim separatism
‚Ä¢ Foundation for Pakistan demand
‚Ä¢ Jinnah shifted from nationalist to communalist
‚Ä¢ Marked end of Hindu-Muslim political unity
‚Ä¢ Path to Partition visible

lahoreCongress.title: Lahore Congress Session (Dec 1929) - PURNA SWARAJ
lahoreCongress.decision:
‚Ä¢ Rejected Nehru Report
‚Ä¢ Adopted PURNA SWARAJ (Complete Independence) as goal
‚Ä¢ Replaced 'Dominion Status' with 'Complete Independence'
‚Ä¢ January 26, 1930 declared as Independence Day
‚Ä¢ Decision to launch Civil Disobedience Movement
‚Ä¢ Tricolor flag unfurled on banks of Ravi
lahoreCongress.independence: January 26, 1930 - First Independence Day celebrated across India with pledge of Purna Swaraj (later became Republic Day)
